summary: Create a professional academic PowerPoint slide deck for the "Kisan Sahayak" project using the provided slide text verbatim, formatted with a minimal white design and blue accents, consistent fonts, and clean icons, using only real (non-AI) images sourced from Google.
architectural_notes: Do not alter provided slide wording; only apply formatting into slides.
Design constraints: minimal design, white background, blue accent, clean icons, consistent font across slides.
Image sourcing constraint: do not use AI-generated images; use only real images sourced from Google.

User provided per-slide image sources as Google Images search query URLs (not direct image URLs); workflow must select a specific real image per slide and paste its direct image URL (or upload), with optional attribution/caption.

User is providing a custom mapping/order of images to specific slides (e.g., slide3=Problem Definition, slide9=Future Scope, slide10=Conclusion, slide2=Research Done, slide7=Prototype Features, slide6=Prototype Suggested, slide4=Empathy Findings, slide11=Prototype Access, slide5=Proposed Solution, slide8=Justification); implementation should support per-slide image assignment accordingly.
known_issues: Image sourcing from Google may require verifying usage rights/attribution before inclusion in the PowerPoint.
Google Images search result links (tbm=isch) are not direct image assets and may not embed/export correctly; need direct image URLs or downloaded/uploaded images.

Some user-provided image references are not directly usable for embedding/export (e.g., `content://...` Android/WhatsApp URIs and `share.google/images/...` share links); PPT export typically requires direct publicly accessible image URLs or explicit file uploads.
In-app slide viewer is not displaying images even when the deck is reported as ready.
Export/download flow is not producing a real downloadable PPTX file/link when requested (no download link available).

existing_features.title: Create a slide deck in the frontend that formats the provided 11 slides exactly as given (verbatim wording) into a professional academic presentation with a minimal design: white background, blue accent color, clean icons, and consistent font across all slides.
Implement slide navigation and presentation viewing UX in the frontend (thumbnail list and/or previous/next controls) so the user can review the formatted slides in order before exporting.
Provide an export function to download the formatted deck as a PowerPoint (.pptx) file that preserves the minimal white + blue styling, consistent fonts, and slide structure.

Add support for using only real (non-AI) images by allowing the user to supply image URLs (e.g., from Google) per slide, plus optional caption/attribution text fields, and include those images in both the on-screen deck and the exported .pptx.

Pre-fill the app’s per-slide image settings for slides 1–10 using the exact URLs provided by the user (Google Images search query URLs), mapped to the corresponding slide numbers, so the user sees images configured immediately when opening each slide’s image panel.

Add clear, English in-app validation and guidance for image URLs that are not direct image assets (including Google Images search result URLs like `google.com/search?tbm=isch...`), so users understand why an image may not load/export and how to fix it by providing a direct image URL.

Add a slide 11-specific option to use a screenshot of the user’s actual prototype by allowing the user to upload an image file from their device for slide 11, and ensure that uploaded image appears in the on-screen slide preview and is embedded in the exported deck.

Add a bulk image upload workflow that assigns the user’s uploaded image files to slides 2–11 in a single action, using the exact slide order the user specified: Slide 3 (Problem Definition), Slide 9 (Future Scope), Slide 10 (Conclusion), Slide 2 (Research Done), Slide 7 (Prototype Features), Slide 6 (Prototype Suggested), Slide 4 (Empathy Findings), Slide 11 (Prototype Access), Slide 5 (Proposed Solution), Slide 8 (Justification). The workflow must let the user confirm/adjust the mapping before export.

Update slide image handling so any slide (not only slide 11) can use an uploaded image file (stored as a data URL in frontend state) and that uploaded image is always preferred over a URL for on-screen preview.

Fix the export so it downloads a true PowerPoint .pptx file (not an .html file), preserving the existing minimal white + blue academic styling and embedding the assigned images for slides 2–11 (and slide 11 prototype image) directly into the .pptx.

Ensure the exported PPTX uses the same slide layout proportions as the on-screen preview (16:9) and scales/crops images consistently so they fit the designated image area without overflowing or distortion.

Fix the on-screen slide preview so assigned images actually render at a visible size whenever a slide has either (a) an uploaded image data URL or (b) a direct image URL, without collapsing to zero height or being hidden by the loading overlay.

Replace the current HTML-based export in frontend/src/pptx/exportDeckToPptx.ts with generation of a real PowerPoint .pptx file download, embedding the slide text and any assigned images (prefer uploadedDataUrl over url) into the PPTX while preserving the existing minimal white + blue academic styling and 16:9 layout.

Update the export UI messaging to reflect the real PPTX download flow (remove references to exporting HTML, printing to PDF, or screenshot instructions) and provide clear English success/error toasts that match the actual exported file type and any image-embed limitations.

new_feature_requests.summary: Format the provided Kisan Sahayak content into a professional academic PowerPoint with minimal white design, blue accents, clean icons, consistent fonts; do not change wording; use only real images from Google (no AI images).
